explanation: Agent A is correct. name_len is assigned once (name_len = i - name_start) and immediately afterwards the code returns if (0 == name_len). There is no later assignment to name_len, so by the time execution reaches mhd_assert(0 != name_len) the condition is provably true on all reachable paths. Thus that assertion is an executed operation whose removal cannot change the functional behaviour of the function (it only re-checks an invariant already enforced by an earlier return). Under MISRA C:2023 Rule 2.2 (dead code) this constitutes dead code. Note: if the mhd_assert macro has intentional observable side-effects (logging, timing-critical behaviour, etc.) the removal could in theory affect behaviour — in that case it would not be dead — but in the common case where mhd_assert only evaluates the condition and aborts on failure, the assertion here is redundant and meets the definition of dead code. Recommended fixes are to remove the assertion, make it compile-time (or debug-only) only, or refactor so the invariant is expressed in a way that does not introduce dead code.
